categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness
categories.description: Algorithm correctness, proper implementation of requirements, handles edge cases appropriately, demonstrates understanding of Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Output & Functionality
categories.description: Produces expected output format, meets all functional requirements, handles input/output correctly, demonstrates working solution.

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code compiles without errors, uses standard Java syntax and conventions, and appropriately utilizes language features for classes, constructors, methods, and basic I/O. The organization into a class with a main method is good.

The implementation correctly fulfills all requirements: the `Cuboid` class has the specified attributes, both constructors are implemented correctly (including the chained constructor using `this`), all getter methods are present, and the `getSurfaceArea` and `getVolume` methods implement the formulas accurately. The test program creates two objects as required and uses them.

The `displayInfo` method correctly prints all the required information (color, dimensions, surface area, volume) for each cuboid object. The output format appears to match the implicit requirements of the problem description, and the functionality of the class and test program is fully demonstrated.

The code follows good practices with clear and descriptive names for classes, attributes, and methods (e.g., `l`, `w`, `h`, `color`, `getSurfaceArea`, `displayInfo`). Indentation and formatting are consistent and readable. While explicit Javadoc comments are missing, the code is self-explanatory for this level of assignment.

feedback.overall_comment: Excellent work on this assignment! The `Cuboid` class is implemented correctly and adheres to all specified requirements. The constructors are well-defined, including the use of `this` to chain them, and all methods perform their intended functions accurately. The test program successfully creates and utilizes two `Cuboid` objects, demonstrating the class's functionality. The code is clean, well-formatted, and easy to understand.
strengths: Correct implementation of both overloaded constructors, including the use of `this` to invoke the other constructor.
Accurate calculation of surface area and volume.
All required getter methods are implemented.
The `displayInfo` method provides clear and comprehensive output for each cuboid.
Well-structured Java code with good naming conventions and formatting.
areas_for_improvement: Consider adding Javadoc comments to the `Cuboid` class and its methods for enhanced documentation, especially for more complex projects.

category_scores.reasoning: Code compiles cleanly, uses proper Java naming conventions, and correctly leverages language features (fields, constructors, methods). No syntax or package/import errors. Minor deduction because the no-arg constructor is not itself invoking the 4-arg constructor with this(), which was explicitly demanded in the constructor specification.

All required algorithmic parts (surface-area, volume, getters) are correct and the program logic creates the two request objects. However, the requirement that the default constructor must call this(...) was ignored, plus the ‘displayInfo’ implementation deviates from the expected format (appending ‘Color:’, ‘Length:’, etc. onto the lines rather than producing the clean sample-run-like show). These omissions make the implementation partially incorrect against the specification.

Two objects are built exactly as requested and the displayed numerics (area, volume) are accurate. The program runs successfully and shows every demanded attribute. However, the wording and ordering (extra labels) don’t strictly follow the sample-run style.

Indentation and naming are good, but there are zero comments and no class javadoc explaining purpose. Variables are minimally named (getL vs getLength) without any documentation describing units or intent.

feedback.overall_comment: Your code compiles, runs and produces logically correct numbers. The biggest gaps are (1) the default constructor should delegate to the 4-argument version using this(), and (2) the display format should echo the sample run more closely. Adding javadoc/comments and more descriptive variable names would improve readability.
strengths: All required fields and methods present
Uses proper access modifiers for encapsulation
areas_for_improvement: Make the no-arg constructor call this(1,1,1,"white") to satisfy the requirement
Print dimensions exactly as in the sample run (no extra labels or rearranged order)
Add comments or JavaDoc describing Cuboid’s purpose and each method
Consider renaming getters (e.g., getLength) for clarity
Provide units in documentation or output to aid usability

misconceptions.name: Constructor delegation misconception
misconceptions.description: Belief that manually assigning default values in the no-arg body is equivalent to constructor-chaining when the assignment specifically required this(...) delegation to avoid duplication.

evidence.note: does not invoke this(...) as required
